node.title: Printout member variables
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE TEAM,
I am adding member variables following the Example 3 : Multiphysics coupling.
I would like to printout member variables for the confirmation.
For example, I would like to printout "_grad_some_variable" in the Example 3.
Please help me.
ExampleConvection.h in Example 3:
const VariableGradient & _grad_some_variable;
ExampleConvection.C in Example 3 :
params.addRequiredCoupledVar("some_variable", "The gradient of this variable will be used as the velocity vector.");
_grad_some_variable(coupledGradient("some_variable"))
ex03.i in Example 3:
[Kernels]
[./conv]
type = ExampleConvection
variable = convected
# Couple a variable into the convection kernel using local_name = simulationg_name syntax
some_variable = diffused
[../]
[]
Sincerely,
Thomas

Hi Thomas
You can look at VariableGradientCompoent to output the gradient to an AuxVariable, then in an exodus file and visualize it there.
Best,
Guillaume

node.title: Possible Bug in Postprocessors::SideFluxIntegral
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I've been running some heat conduction in a very simple geometry focused at returning heat fluxes on a surface. I recently updated to the current Master branch of MOOSE (I was previously on a Master checkpoint from around January) and after that my heat fluxes have had a bug.
After the initial construction, on the very first non-linear iteration, the heat fluxes are reported in the ~30kW range, when they should be basically zero. This is correct by the next non-linear iteration, and is correct in the initial construction phase, which is confusing.
I recompiled everything in devel mode and ran GDB to see if I could find where it goes wrong, and I went all the way down to the calculation step in SideFluxIntegral.C --> "return -MetaPhysicL::raw_value(_diffusion_coef[_qp]) * _grad_u[_qp] * _normals[_qp];". The reported value by _grad_u is wrong. I don't know how to go any deeper than this, so I'm coming to y'all. I've attached my input and geometry files so you can replicate, I got the same bug by using the HeatConduction module to execute. For now I'm going to start checking out older checkpoints of the Master branch to see if I can find the date when the bug begins, but hopefully one of you can find the problem first.
Also attached is a VectorOfPostprocessors VectorPostprocessor C file that I added printing functions to, in order to see the values of the fluxes at every non-linear step, so you can see that the bug isn't in my variable printing.
This is the output of one run:

node.title: Error : Your current working directory is in a git repository || Moose Installation
node.bodyText:
I have installed moose and it passed all the tests. When I execute these commands,
$ cd ~/projects
$ ./moose/scripts/stork.sh cat
there is an error : your current working directory is in a git repository
I am unable to run stork.sh file to create an application. Thanks in advance.

What does the following report?
cd ~/projects
git worktree list
It sounds as if your projects directory (or perhaps the parent directory) is a git repo. I would like to understand more before we simply 'remove' this offending git repo. I know some use git as a means to back up everything...
Hey, git worktree list is returning : Users/stheeda  0000000 [master].
@milljm searched in google and did execute this command "rm -rf .git" in the projects directory. Now It works fine. But I don't know if this is 'legit'

@stheeda07 it does fix your immediate problem, if you didn't intend to make your home directory a git repository. If you did want it to be a git repository, well now the history associated with git is no longer available, unless there was some sort of backup elsewhere.

@cticenhour I never wanted my home directory to be a git repository. May be something might've gone wrong during git setup (not sure though). Anyways I have a backup of all the files on my parent directory

node.title: No Abaqus->LibMesh mapping information for ElemType QUAD8!
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I was planning to manually generate a mesh in ABAQUS mesh format. The elements should be second order elements, like CPE8 in ABAQUS (QUAD8 In libmesh). However, when I ran the simulation, there was an error "No Abaqus->LibMesh mapping information for ElemType QUAD8!". Does anyone know how to generate mesh with second order elements that MOOSE can read? Or does anyone know how to use 3x3 quadrature rule for CPE4 (QUAD4) elements in MOOSE?
Thanks,
Jack

There should be a QUAD9 in libMesh, but I don't think Abaqus supports QUAD9.  If you're in a pinch, however, Cubit can export QUAD9 elements via Exodus which should be supported by libMesh.  You could test with the free non-commercial license of Coreform Cubit: https://coreform.com/products/coreform-cubit/free-meshing-software/
That being said, it certainly seems like the QUAD8 should be supported, so this seems like a bug.  But generally speaking, I think you can expect Exodus files to have better support in libMesh than Abaqus files (@permcody, true statement?).
Thanks, I used Cubit to create the Exodus mesh. It works great!

node.title: where is the old wiki?
node.bodyText: I wanted to point @Traiwit to some plasticity documentation on there, but can't find it
It is dead, we don't have the resources to host it any longer, see  #15932
What specific information were you looking for? It might be somewhere in the new docs. If it is not, we should migrate them over.
Thank you @milljm and @aeslaughter .   This was very useful, and i just wanted to confirm that we got all the required doco.

👍
I have shut down the AWS server...

@milljm Re-enabled the old wiki. It will be up until the end of the day on Friday (4-16-2021). If you want something please grab the content and either submit a PR or paste the content into #15932. The content is very old, out-of-date, and it ends up costing personal money to host the site. After this, it is gone and whatever was "needed" should be replaced with new content.
Thanks for this @aeslaughter and @milljm
Oh, i see that last year i put my request into #15932 .   Did anyone ever action those requests (i didn't) ?
I've downloaded everything i need, thank you @milljm .  It'd be appreciated if you could keep the AWS going for a few more hours to give @Traiwit a chance to download.

@Traiwit - i suggest you grab the following pages:
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/HardSoft/
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/ReturnMap/ (i think this is in the current doco too)
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/CTO/
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/WeakPlaneTensile/
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/WeakPlaneShear/
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/Tensile/
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/MC/
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/DP/
https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/TensorMechanicsBasics/PoroMechanics/
Hi @WilkAndy thank you much appreciated! I will go through them today :)

node.title: Phase Field Fracture model with shell elements?
node.bodyText:
I am modeling the fracture of a long fiber reinforced composite material and would like to use shell elements (each layer is one shell element).
As anything like that been done with MOOSE? I've been searching through the examples in "combined" for TesnorMechnics +PhaseField stuff but haven't found anything.
It is also unclear to me how we can choose either plane tress or plane strain, or other types of elements.
Thanks for the assistance!
Martim
We have not implemented phase field fracture model for shell elements.  As for now,  maybe you have to consider to use solid elements.

node.title: Ramp Function
node.bodyText: I am using the NS module to solve the transient problem of a cylinder in a flow channel. I will need to model a parabolic velocity profile at the inlet, but the velocity needs to ramp up gradually in a period of time to its steady state value. Is there a way to define a ramping function in moose?

I was able to determine the easiest usable method was to define the following function:
[Functions]
[./exact_fn]
type = ParsedFunction
value = 'if(t < 0.05, 0, 1e-4*(1.2-y)*y)'
[../]
[]
It appears to have worked well for my application.

node.title: How to impement plastic strain-softening with DP/MC model + quick question on dilatant angle
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE user,
Q1
I've just started to implement DP/MC (nonlinear) to my mine simulation.
I'm currently trying to work on strain-softening, in theory, coh and/or friction angle should be a function of the accumulated plastic strain, is there a way to implement this with moose.
so far I got DP/CM to work, but yet cannot implement softening. is there any suggestion?
Note that, we do not want to use cosserat/capped model at this stage.
Q2
Also another quick question regarding dilatant angle: when I implement initial_stress into the model, it gives out an error during the excavation step when I set the dilatant angle to be relatively low, for example, less than 10 degree, but the simulation works fine with it is around 20 degree. is this because the geometry is too soft and cannot handle the initial stress?
  [./ini_xx]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '-2*9.81*2700*(1000-z)'
  [../]
  [./ini_yy]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '-2*9.81*2700*(1000-z)'
  [../]
  [./ini_zz]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '-9.81*2700*(1000-z)'
  [../]

++++++++++++++++++++++++
Checking the derivatives
++++++++++++++++++++++++
Debug Parameters are as follows
stress = 


*** ERROR ***
The debug parameters have the wrong size


Thank you very much.
Kind regards,
Traiwit
@WilkAndy

Well done for getting plasticity to work with your model.  Honestly, with caving as well it is a very difficult numerical problem.  To implement strain softening, use another TensorMechanicsHardening object, such as TensorMechanicsHardeningCubic or Exponential or CutExponential.
You are almost definitely correct about the small angle not being able to support the initial stress.

By the way, although these hardening/softening functions haven't been documented in the "new" system (actually years and years old), there is documentation at, for instance
test/tests/mohr_coulomb/hard_cubic.xlsx
test/tests/mohr_coulomb/hard1_2.xlsx
and other ".xlsx" files in the tensor_mechanics directory

Hi @WilkAndy,
Thank you! this defs helps a lot! I really wish MOOSE documentation is friendlier for new users.
just a quick question, what would be the value of 'internal parameter' in this case? is it plastic stain, or do I have to manually define it? I see the example defines it as shown below, not sure if it related.
  [./mc_int_auxk]
    type = MaterialStdVectorAux
    index = 0
    property = plastic_internal_parameter
    variable = mc_int
  [../]

Kind regards,
Traiwit

It's kind of my fault that the doco is not great, sorry.  When i initially developed all these plasticity models, MOOSE was using a different doco system, and although the doco is quite good, i haven't had the time to translate it across.
You don't need to define the internal param - your plasticity model (MC/DP) will do that for you.   Look at, eg
./test/tests/capped_mohr_coulomb/capped_mohr_coulomb.pdf

There is stuff on the "old wiki" but i can't get to that now.

Thank you @WilkAndy! I kinda get the idea now, I'll let you know if it works on my mine simulation
Kind regards,
Traiwit

Hi @WilkAndy, softening can be added to my simulation with no problem.
I have a quick question here: what is 'plastic_internal_parameter', how does moose calculate this parameter, I guess it's associated with plastic_strain, but couldn't find its definition anywhere.
not sure if it's the 'increment in total strain' from the docco from oldwiki (https://ec2-18-237-134-137.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/wiki/PhysicsModules/TensorMechanics/ReturnMap/)
Kind regards,
Traiwit

Generally, the "plastic_internal_parameter" is called q in the documentation.  For instance, about halfway down the MohrCoulomb doco you can see
The hardening law is defined through
h = −1 . so that q = qold + γ, so that q is the accumulated sum of γ over all "time steps".

The general case is written about 1/3rd of the way down the 2nd page of "Plasticity and the Return-Mapping Algorithm":
the increment in plastic strain is defined to be
pNαα ε ̇ = ∑ γ r . ij ij
α=1 This is the flow rule for plastic strain.  Similarly, the increment in the internal variables is
Nαα q ̇ = − ∑ γ h .
aa α=1
These are the flow rules for the internal parameters.

(the fonts are screwed up here - you can see the original on the webpage).
So, to figure out how an "internal variable" increases at a timestep, you use "h", and that relates the increase to "gamma".  In the MC case, \dot{q} = gamma.  Then, to figure out "gamma", you use the flow rule.  In the MC case this is epsilon_plastic = gamma * df/dsigma = \dot{q} * df/dsigma.   This gives physical meaning to the term "plastic strain".  In the MC case, df/dsigma is a horrible function that you can work out using the "Identities" webpage, but the "internal variable" is just telling you the magnitude of this plastic strain.
Roughly speaking, for MC, the size of the plastic strain and hence the "internal variable" is just what you'd intuitively think of as the plastic shear strain.

perfect! That makes sense!
Thanks again @WilkAndy
my next step would be either adding discontinuity (fault) into the model OR moving to explicit method to improve the computation time (we try to replicate Abaqus explicit solver for mining simulation)

node.title: unused options?

Would anyone know what this warning is about? The input.hit file has not changed but I did update and recompile MOOSE completely.

WARNING! There are options you set that were not used!

Option left: name:-i value: engy5310p1/input.hit

The .pvtu extension should be used when writing VTK files in libMesh.

      1 Linear |R| = 4.575783e-03
      2 Linear |R| = 1.632349e-04
      3 Linear |R| = 4.449145e-06
 2 Nonlinear |R| = 1.366984e-05
 Solve Converged!

Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+
| time           | bulk-energy    |
+----------------+----------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   1.000000e+00 |  -3.395251e+10 |
+----------------+----------------+

The .pvtu extension should be used when writing VTK files in libMesh.
FINAL:

Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+
| time           | bulk-energy    |
+----------------+----------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   1.000000e+00 |  -3.395251e+10 |
|   2.000000e+00 |  -3.395251e+10 |
+----------------+----------------+

WARNING! There are options you set that were not used!
WARNING! could be spelling mistake, etc!
There is one unused database option. It is:
Option left: name:-i value: engy5310p1/input.hit
I am guessing that in this input file you have some options being passed to PETSc that at not correct.

Just about anything I run gives me that warning...
->  ./engy5310p1-opt --check-input -i input.hit

Syntax OK
WARNING! There are options you set that were not used!
WARNING! could be spelling mistake, etc!
There are 2 unused database options. They are:
Option left: name:--check-input (no value)
Option left: name:-i value: input.hit

The solver section is:
[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]
Try naming the file to "input.i", perhaps we are not expecting .hit.

I get the same output.
I don't seem to find the warnings in the MOOSE framework source code.
Thanks.
You are right, @dealmeidavf : this warning does not come from MOOSE or libmesh.  Perhaps it comes from your VTK writer?
I think it is coming from PETSc, but I am not sure why.
I believe you have your PETSc compiled in debug mode where this check is automatically enabled. You can safely ignore it.

node.title: No such file or directory
node.bodyText:
Hi, I got MOOSE installed and i tried creating an application with the command: cd ~/projects
However, i got an error message saying: bash: cd: /root/projects: No such file or directory
I checked the MOOSE folder and there is a file named projects
Any help as to how to get this solved?
Thank you

Hello
cd ~/projects means change directory to projects in the home (~) directory.
Except you created the projects directory in the moose directory instead of the home directory.
You could restart the tutorial from the beginning to correct that.
We recommend the directory structure to be something like:
(moose) guillaume@ubuntu1:~/projects$ pwd
/home/guillaume/projects
(moose) guillaume@ubuntu1:~/projects$ ll
total 136
drwxrwxr-x 18 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 13 18:54 ./
drwxr-xr-x 29 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 14 22:47 ../
drwxrwxr-x 20 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 13 19:03 moose/
drwxrwxr-x 20 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 13 19:03 your_application/

with moose and your application in the projects folder under the home directory.
This is not a moose issue, you will find more help on linux help forums.
Guillaume
There seems to be a bigger issue than that... @kwarteng10 are you using the root user?  It's really not a good idea.  I would suggest adding a "regular" user and logging in with that.

How do I add a regular user
Sorry I am new to Ubuntu, so I seem to be lost

I am running ubuntu on windows sir
…
On Thu, 15 Apr 2021 at 23:54, Derek Gaston ***@***.***> wrote:
 There seems to be a bigger issue than that... @kwarteng10
 <https://github.com/kwarteng10> are you using the root user? It's really
 not a good idea. I would suggest adding a "regular" user and logging in
 with that.

 —

 <#17611 (comment)>,
 or unsubscribe
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AORERKHJGLZ3QCM5ZSWDCKDTI4D5FANCNFSM426RZLBA>
 .

You mean I am running from a wrong directory?
…

 directory.
 Except you created the projects directory in the moose directory instead
 of the home directory.

 You could restart the tutorial from the beginning to correct that.
 We recommend the directory structure to be something like:

 (moose) ***@***.***:~/projects$ pwd
 /home/guillaume/projects

 total 136
 drwxrwxr-x 18 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 13 18:54 ./
 drwxr-xr-x 29 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 14 22:47 ../
 drwxrwxr-x 20 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 13 19:03 moose/
 drwxrwxr-x 20 guillaume guillaume  4096 Apr 13 19:03 your_application/

 with moose and your application in the projects folder under the home
 directory.

 This is not a moose issue, you will find more help on linux help forums.

 Guillaume
